title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.43 | 17-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: Om Agyanati Miran Dhasya Gyanan Janishalakaya Chaksharon Meelitam Yena Tasmai Sri Gurave Namaha
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and mantras, invoking blessings and paying respects to spiritual teachers.

segments.key_quote: She could not tolerate Ashwatthama's being bound by ropes and being a devoted lady she said release him for he is a Brahmana our spiritual master
segments.summary: The speaker introduces the 43rd verse of the 7th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, focusing on Draupadi's reaction to Ashwatthama being bound and her plea for his release due to his status as a Brahmana.

segments.key_quote: she offered him respect out of being good-natured, mild-natured and in spite of being aggrieved because of the inglorious murder committed by this Ashwatthama
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on Draupadi's motivations for showing respect to Ashwatthama despite his heinous act, highlighting her good nature and cultural understanding.

segments.key_quote: a teacher or spiritual master is liable to be rejected if he proves that he is the son of a Brahmana himself unworthy of the position of a guru or spiritual master
segments.summary: The speaker discusses why Arjuna arrested Ashwatthama, even knowing he was a Brahmana and the son of Dronacharya, explaining that scriptures dictate a guru can be rejected if unworthy.

segments.key_quote: Ashwatthama failed to discharge the duties of a Brahmana or teacher why because he committed the most inglorious murder and therefore he was liable to be rejected from the exalted position of a Brahmana
segments.summary: The speaker defines the role of a Guru and Acharya, emphasizing the importance of living by example and assimilating scriptures, and reiterates that Ashwatthama's actions warranted rejection from his position, contrasting Krishna and Arjuna's view with Draupadi's.

segments.key_quote: But the shastras say the son of the brahmana if he is not qualified as a brahmana he should not be accepted as a brahmana.
segments.summary: The speaker contrasts Draupadi's customary respect for Ashwatthama as a Brahmana's son with the shastric view that one's qualities, not birth, determine their social standing and respect, emphasizing Ashwatthama's degraded behavior.

segments.key_quote: Arjuna did not kill him. And Draupadi did not even withdraw the respect. This is a very, very advanced culture in human society, very advanced culture.
segments.summary: The speaker highlights the Vedic culture's emphasis on proper respect, noting that while Krishna urged Arjuna to kill Ashwatthama, Arjuna refrained due to respect for his guru's son, and Draupadi maintained her respect, showcasing an advanced cultural understanding.

segments.key_quote: These are the characteristics of one who is a pure devotee of the Lord. A devotee of the Lord can tolerate all sorts of tribulations personally.
segments.summary: The speaker reiterates the Vedic culture's training in offering proper respects and emphasizes Draupadi's actions as characteristic of a pure devotee who can tolerate personal tribulations.

segments.key_quote: in spite of so much tribulation a devotee tolerate such tribulations and never are unkind to others even to the enemy Draupadi did not show any any any consideration had don't have any consideration that he is enemy
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes Draupadi's tolerance and lack of unkindness even towards her enemy, highlighting that a pure devotee is decorated with saintly qualities, referencing SB 1.2.6.

segments.key_quote: easiest way of purification of the contamination in the heart then one displays all behaves exhibits all the divine qualities that is the conclusion
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by stating that pure devotion is essential for bringing out the good qualities of a person, which are covered by material contamination, and that devotional service is the easiest way to purify the heart and exhibit divine qualities.
